subject: RE: [TDD] OT: Request for example -- boolean parameters
msgSnippet: Take a look at The TableCellRenderer & TreeCellRenderer interfaces in Java (the interface methods are below) public Component
messageBody:
Take a look at The TableCellRenderer & TreeCellRenderer interfaces in Java
(the interface methods are below)


public Component getTreeCellRendererComponent(JTree tree,
Object value,
boolean selected,
boolean expanded,
boolean leaf,
int row,
boolean hasFocus)


public Component getTableCellRendererComponent(JTable table,
Object value,
boolean isSelected,
boolean hasFocus,
int row,
int column)



HTH


Andy

> -----Original Message-----
> From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains@...]
> Sent: 09 June 2003 22:44
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com; extremeprogramming@yahoogroups.com;
> testdrivendevelopment@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [TDD] OT: Request for example -- boolean parameters
>
>
> Hello, everyone.
>
> In the midst of my current writing project I am describing
> replacing difficult-to-understand parameters with
> easier-to-understand ones. My particular example is boolean
> flags: in a positional-parameter language like Java, C or Ruby,
> it's virtually impossible to know just by looking at a method
> call what "true" or "false" mean, especially in a method that has
> several such flags in the same parameter list.
>
> What I'd love is a real-life example of this, preferably from a
> well-known library. If anyone has, by chance, come across one of
> these monsters, I'd appreciate a reference.
>
> In other words, a method like doIt(myObject, anotherObject, true,
> false, true, true);
>
> What the hell does true, false, true, true mean?!
>
> BTW: I'd appreciate a CC: to me directly by e-mail, especially
> from the XP mailing list, since I can't keep up with the traffic
> on that list.
>
> Thanks a bunch everyone!
>
>
> J. B. Rainsberger,
> President, Diaspar Software Services
> Let's write software that people understand.
> http://www.diasparsoftware.com/
> telephone: +1 416 791-8603
